source.name: Merkle Tree Structure
source.instructions: Which of the following best describes the structure of a Merkle Tree?

answers.answer: A binary tree where each non-leaf node is the hash of its two child nodes
A linked list where each node contains the hash of the previous node
A complete binary tree where only leaf nodes contain data
A balanced tree where each node contains both data and its hash
It is a linear data structure like an array.

source.guidance: The correct answer is "A binary tree where each non-leaf node is the hash of its two child nodes". This accurately describes the structure of a Merkle Tree as presented in the topic. In a Merkle Tree, leaf nodes contain hashes of data blocks, and each non-leaf node is the hash of its child nodes' hashes. The other options are incorrect: a linked list is not a tree structure, a Merkle Tree is not necessarily a complete binary tree, and nodes in a Merkle Tree do not contain both data and hashes (only leaf nodes contain data hashes).
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the structure and properties of a Merkle Tree
